dt: {bc}to bring to a more satisfactory state:
{bc}to bring the parts of to a true or more effective relative position
{bc}to determine the amount to be paid under an insurance policy in settlement of (a loss)
{bc}to adapt or conform oneself (as to new conditions)

dt.t: Our eyes gradually {wi}adjusted{/wi} to the darkness.

dt: {bc}to achieve mental and behavioral balance between one's own needs and the demands of others

pt: {sc}adapt{/sc} {sc}adjust{/sc} {sc}accommodate{/sc} {sc}conform{/sc} {sc}reconcile{/sc} mean to bring one thing into correspondence with another. {sc}adapt{/sc} implies a modification according to changing circumstances.
{sc}adjust{/sc} suggests bringing into a close and exact correspondence or harmony such as exists between parts of a mechanism.

pt.t: {it}adjusted{/it} the budget to allow for inflation

pt: {sc}accommodate{/sc} may suggest yielding or compromising to effect a correspondence.

pt.t: businesses {it}accommodating{/it} themselves to the new political reality

pt: {sc}conform{/sc} applies to bringing into accordance with a pattern, example, or principle.
{sc}reconcile{/sc} implies the demonstration of the underlying compatibility of things that seem to be incompatible.

pt.t: tried to {it}reconcile{/it} what he said with what I knew

et: borrowed from French {it}ajuster{/it} (earlier and Middle French also spelled {it}adjuster{/it}), going back to Old French {it}ajouster{/it} "to make comply with," from {it}a-{/it} (going back to Latin {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-}) + {it}-jouster,{/it} verbal derivative of {it}juste{/it} "right, exact" {ma}{mat|just:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to bring to a more satisfactory state:

dt: {bc}a mortgage having an interest rate which is usually initially lower than that of a mortgage with a fixed rate but is adjusted periodically according to the cost of funds to the lender

shortdef: a mortgage having an interest rate which is usually initially lower than that of a mortgage with a fixed rate but is adjusted periodically according to the cost of funds to the lender
